text: - Hi, my name is Leonardo Murillo,
and I build cloud service in AWS
using products in the AWS Marketplace.
Thank you for joining me.

We're going to be talking
about industry trends,
challenges, and how you can solve them.

Today I want us to talk
about generative AI,

large language models, and what
they have meant to the stack

that most organizations
have to support today.
Because over the past years,

there's been a huge focus
in trying to grab control
of the expanding complexity, right?
The average system architecture today
incorporates distributed services,
multiple systems to store and query data,

and basically an explosive
combination of tools,

all of which turns into growing
cognitive load to teams.
And there's been a trend
towards decreasing that stack diversity
and system complexity altogether.

And platform engineering
has surfaced, for example,
to try and make sure that organizations

are actually following some
well-established patterns
and that teams have access to proven tools
and templates that they can easily deploy.
And perhaps more importantly than that,
that operations and cloud and security

and basically everybody
else that's involved,
not just in making sure that stuff runs,

but also that it stays running,
they feel confident in.

And I think we've made solid
strides in the right direction.
I think containers have become the norm.

Running them in Kubernetes
is pretty much a standard.
The cloud has come to remove a lot

of the undifferentiated effort
in keeping the lights on.
And developing tools,

think for example, Visual
Studio Code, right?

They've pretty much landed
on solid ground too.
So where am I going with this?

Machine learning is coming
to disrupt this, otherwise,
improving scenario of software engineering
and system operations
that we've built over the last few years.
And not for no reason.

Because the stuff that you're
now able to do with models

that are basically readily
available, you know,

foundational models
available off the shelf,
and managed services such as Bedrock

that gives you access to
them with a couple of clicks,
is resulting in, yet again,

a growth in the complexity and
diversity of our tech stacks.
Think of RAG, for example,
retrieval-augmented generation,

which is an incredibly efficient
way to enrich the context
that an LLM has with data

without having to
fine-tune or train a model.
Every RAG implementation

is going to require some
form of vector storage.
Vectors are the representations of data

that you can use to
basically search content
given certain similarity,

for instance, to what
the LLM is generating.

And with every pilot that's
being built out there,

one or more vector storage
tools and solutions are added
to the stack of organizations.
So my question was,
what if there was some vector storage

that was already available
in most organizations
that we could just use?

And this is coming from my own
personal experience because,

I'm pretty sure like
most of you out there,

I was trying my own
version of an LLM prototype

that was going to make me rich
and revolutionize the world.
And I was going through that exercise

and I started trying all
these different specialized
databases that do vector data alone.
And I was wasting so much time,

I was wasting time familiarizing
myself with the tool,

getting the right
developer tooling in place,
learning how to use the developer tools.

And I was spending more
time doing all that
than actually building my prototype.
And then I stumbled into something
that I did not anticipate.
My good old and trusty Redis
that I've used for many, many years

as a key-value store, pretty
much, also supported vectors.

And I was able to use
all my existing tooling

and I was able to interact
with the same commands
and use the same patterns

that I had already grown so
comfortable with over the years.
And Redis, that I had picked in the past
because how performing it was,
still satisfied the super fast responses
that made me choose it
as a solution for caching or queues
or similar scenarios in the past.
But the best part of it

was that it introduced
zero additional complexity
to my tech stack.
So here's two pieces of advice:
If you need to store vectors,
look into your existing tech stack

because maybe there's something
in there that already works

and you don't have to
bring in something new.
And for the Redis users out there,

which are pretty much
everybody that I know,
and you're looking for something flexible
that does seemingly everything well,

whether it's key-value
or now even the vectors,

I really encourage you
to give Redis a shot
for your RAG implementation.
And you can actually try it out

just by looking Redis
in the AWS Marketplace

or clicking the link
that is in the article
where you found this video.

And you can use it for
free for a few weeks.
And as part of this series,
I'm going to release a hands-on lab

to teach you how to actually
do this step by step.

So I hope I'll see you
all soon. Thank you.
